member.name: T:CryptSharp.Utility.SCrypt
member.summary: Implements the SCrypt key derivation function.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Utility.SCrypt.ComputeDerivedKey(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes a derived key.
member.param: The key to derive from.
The salt. A unique salt means a unique SCrypt stream, even if the original key is identical.
The cost parameter, typically a fairly large number such as 262144. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The mixing block size, typically 8. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The level of parallelism, typically 1. CPU time scales approximately linearly with this parameter.
The maximum number of threads to spawn to derive the key. This is limited by the value. null will use as many threads as possible.
The desired length of the derived key.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Utility.SCrypt.GetEffectivePbkdf2Salt(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: The SCrypt algorithm creates a salt which it then uses as a one-iteration PBKDF2 key stream with SHA256 HMAC. This method lets you retrieve this intermediate salt.
member.param: The key to derive from.
The salt. A unique salt means a unique SCrypt stream, even if the original key is identical.
The cost parameter, typically a fairly large number such as 262144. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The mixing block size, typically 8. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The level of parallelism, typically 1. CPU time scales approximately linearly with this parameter.
The maximum number of threads to spawn to derive the key. This is limited by the value. null will use as many threads as possible.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Utility.SCrypt.GetStream(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Creates a derived key stream from which a derived key can be read.
member.param: The key to derive from.
The salt. A unique salt means a unique scrypt stream, even if the original key is identical.
The cost parameter, typically a fairly large number such as 262144. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The mixing block size, typically 8. Memory usage and CPU time scale approximately linearly with this parameter.
The level of parallelism, typically 1. CPU time scales approximately linearly with this parameter.
The maximum number of threads to spawn to derive the key. This is limited by the value. null will use as many threads as possible.

member.summary: The minimum number for .

member.name: F:CryptSharp.CrypterProperty.MaxRounds
member.summary: The maximum number for .

member.name: T:CryptSharp.BlowfishCrypterVariant
member.summary:
Variations of the Blowfish crypt algorithm.
You only need concern yourself with Blowfish crypt variations if you have passwords generated pre-2011 using the C-language crypt_blowfish library or a port thereof.
CryptSharp was implemented from specification and is not a port, and therefore never had the bug these variants pertain to.

member.name: F:CryptSharp.BlowfishCrypterVariant.Unspecified
member.summary:
The $2a$ prefix indicates nothing about whether or not the crypted password was created with a pre-2011 version of the C-language crypt_blowfish library. Pre-2011, that library had a sign extension bug affecting non-ASCII passwords.
See for a more detailed explanation of the bug in question.

member.name: F:CryptSharp.BlowfishCrypterVariant.Compatible
member.summary:
The $2x$ prefix indicates that these passwords were generated with pre-2011 crypt_blowfish or a port originating from it.
If you have old crypted non-ASCII passwords you can't re-derive, and still want to verify them with CryptSharp, ensure that they have the $2x$ prefix instead of the $2a$ prefix. This will indicate to CryptSharp that it should emulate the bug when verifying the password.

member.name: F:CryptSharp.BlowfishCrypterVariant.Corrected
member.summary:
The $2y$ prefix indicates that pre-2011 crypt_blowfish's sign extension bug does not affect these crypted passwords.
For passwords crypted with CryptSharp, this has always been true and as such selecting this variant changes the prefix but otherwise does not affect the output.

member.name: T:CryptSharp.Crypter

member.returns: true if the algorithm is compatible.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String,CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string. Options modify the crypt operation.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.
Options modifying the crypt operation.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string and a salt string.
The salt can be produced using . Because crypted passwords take the form algorithm+salt+hash, if you pass a crypted password as the salt parameter, the same algorithm and salt will be used to re-crypt the password. Since randomness comes from the salt, the same salt means the same hash, and so the same crypted password will result. Therefore, this method can both generate *and* verify crypted passwords.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.
The salt string or crypted password containing a salt string.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes.
member.param: The bytes of the password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[],CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes. Options modify the crypt operation.
member.param: The bytes of the password.
Options modifying the crypt operation.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes and a salt string.
The salt can be produced using . Because crypted passwords take the form algorithm+salt+hash, if you pass a crypted password as the salt parameter, the same algorithm and salt will be used to re-crypt the password. Since randomness comes from the salt, the same salt means the same hash, and so the same crypted password will result. Therefore, this method can both generate *and* verify crypted passwords.
member.param: The bytes of the password.
The salt string or crypted password containing a salt string.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt
member.summary: Generates a salt string with default options. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a salt string using the specified number of rounds. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt(CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary:
Generates a salt string. Options are used to modify the salt generation. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.
Randomness in a crypted password comes from its salt string, as do all recorded options. The same salt string, when combined with the same password, will generate the same crypted password. If the salt string differs, the same password will generate a different crypted password (crypted passwords have the form algorithm+salt+hash, so the salt is always carried along with the crypted password).
member.param: Options modifying the salt generation.

member.summary: Compares two strings in a timing-insensitive manner.
member.param: The string controlled by a potential attacker.
The string not controlled by a potential attacker.
member.returns: true if the strings are equal.
member.remarks: If the reference string is zero-length, this method does not protect it against timing attacks. If the reference string is extremely long, memory caching effects may reveal that fact.

member.name: T:CryptSharp.Utility.Base32Encoding
member.summary:
Base-32 binary to text encodings.
I needed multiple variations of base-64 for the various crypt algorithms, and base-16 (hex) for test vectors, so base-32 is mostly a freebie. It's great for e-mail verifications, product keys - really anywhere you need someone to type in a randomly-generated code.

member.name: P:CryptSharp.Utility.Base32Encoding.Crockford
member.summary: Crockford base-32 is somewhat traditional, but still better than the RFC 4648 standard. It is specified at http://www.crockford.com/wrmg/base32.html.

member.name: P:CryptSharp.Utility.Base32Encoding.ZBase32
member.summary: z-base-32 is a lowercase base-32 encoding designed to be easily hand-written and read. It is specified at http://www.zer7.com/files/oss/cryptsharp/zbase32.txt.

member.name: T:CryptSharp.Sha512Crypter
member.summary: SHA512 crypt. A reasonable choice if you cannot use Blowfish crypt for policy reasons.

member.summary: Creates a new PBKDF2 stream.
member.param: The HMAC algorithm to use, for example . Make sure to set .
The salt. A unique salt means a unique PBKDF2 stream, even if the original key is identical.
The number of iterations to apply.

member.summary: Reads from the derived key stream.

member.summary: Computes a derived key.
member.param: The HMAC algorithm to use, for example . Make sure to set .
The salt. A unique salt means a unique derived key, even if the original key is identical.
The number of iterations to apply.
The desired length of the derived key.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Utility.Pbkdf2.Close
member.summary: Closes the stream, clearing memory and disposing of the HMAC algorithm.

member.name: P:CryptSharp.Utility.Pbkdf2.Length
member.summary: The maximum number of bytes that can be derived is 2^32-1 times the HMAC size.

member.summary: The position within the derived key stream.

member.name: T:CryptSharp.Utility.EksBlowfishKeyExpansionFlags
member.summary: Modifiers for Expensive Key Schedule (EKS) Blowfish key expansion behavior.

member.name: F:CryptSharp.Utility.EksBlowfishKeyExpansionFlags.None
member.summary: Default behavior.

member.name: F:CryptSharp.Utility.EksBlowfishKeyExpansionFlags.EmulateCryptBlowfishSignExtensionBug
member.summary:
The EksBlowfish code in CryptSharp was implemented as per the specification at http://static.usenix.org/event/usenix99/provos/provos_html/node4.html.
Many other BCrypt implementations, however, are ports originating originating with the crypt_blowfish C implementation. Pre-2011, crypt_blowfish had a sign extension bug that caused up to three characters previous to any 8-bit character to match 0xFF.
CryptSharp never had this bug. However, for those who need backwards compatibility for old password databases created with one of these libraries, I have added *support* for the bug. You can enable it with this flag.

member.name: T:CryptSharp.MD5Crypter
member.summary: MD5 crypt, supported by nearly all systems. A variant supports Apache htpasswd files.
